key_dates.description: Turning point date (range: May 7-8). First key cycle date. Market should settle direction early in the month.
Turning point date - second cycle date. Coincides with broad market volatility window identified across multiple assets.
Turning point date (range: May 21-22). Third cycle date in the month.
Turning point date - final cycle date of the month.

seasonal: May is generally a positive month for oil. Over the last 30 years, multi-seasonal statistics show: May 9 approximately 68% probability of upward movement, May 13 approximately 71% probability of upward movement, May 23 approximately 70% probability of upward movement, May 27 approximately 69% probability of decline, May 28 approximately 71% probability of upward movement. Oil closed at a higher price on May 13 compared to May 6 in approximately 73% of cases (22 out of 30 years).

Over the last 30 years, approximately 71% probability of upward movement around May 13.
Over the last 30 years, approximately 70% probability of upward movement around May 23.
Over the last 30 years, approximately 69% probability of decline around May 27.
Over the last 30 years, approximately 71% probability of upward movement around May 28.
In the last 30 years, oil closed higher on May 13 compared to its price on May 6 in approximately 73% of cases (22 out of 30).

insights: Oil stands at a crossroads in May 2025 as a conjunction of seasonal and historical time cycles converge - providing strong reference points but with mixed directional signals.
Not every month is a parade of success - but when viewed through the right lens, the methodology reveals the footprints behind it. April restored order in grand fashion.

April demonstrated that even with 50% hit rate on turning point dates, significant profit was achievable because the moves that did work (from the dates that were captured) delivered the month's significant movements.

Oil turning point dates, especially combined with oil's strong price volatility, reveal time after time the power of key levels - support, resistance, and cyclical structures working together for risk management and sometimes holding positions exactly to the right moment.

In the last nine months, oil has provided a fascinating testing ground. Even when not every cycle responded to the classical pattern, capturing the right cycle timing delivered substantial results: April approximately 30%, February approximately 13.5%, January over 20%, December approximately 12%, November approximately 11.5% (on two cycles only), October approximately 20% (also on two cycles), September approximately 32%, August approximately 30%.
Over 163% cumulative movement - not from bets or gambling but from dates provided in advance, as part of an orderly, measured, and methodical process.
On the weekly chart, the overall trend in oil has reversed to bearish after a clear break of a support zone that held for three years in the weekly range between $65.50 and $62.50.
A correction attempt was noted around $64.85 but was rejected, powerfully reinforcing the bearish case with the turning point date at April 23.

Relevant resistance levels on the weekly timeframe are positioned between $64.40 and $66.50. The fact that oil has been below this zone for more than five weekly candles points to continued selling pressure on any rally attempt.
Historical support break strengthens the probability for continued decline toward $51. If that level also settles, the next significant support area is around $43.40.
The daily chart shows support and resistance levels from the attached chart. Key price zones for the daily timeframe are marked on the chart.

Oil in May 2025 is expected to present a continuation of the bearish trend with seasonal and historical cycles converging. The pattern suggests a stabilization on strength, based on the broader environment. May could mark a turning point from decline to a new phase or the beginning of a deeper decline.

Specific attention to the May 16-18 window (aligning with the broader geopolitical/seismic cycle window across assets) and the time period of May 21-22 where another cycle date could accelerate or reverse the trend.

support.description: Lower boundary of three-year weekly support range that was recently broken. Now serves as reference point.
First significant historical support level below the broken range. Potential target based on Fibonacci extensions.
Deeper historical support level. Breaking this would confirm the bear case significantly.
Next significant support zone if $51 breaks. Major long-term support level.
Current zone of interest combined with 20-day moving average. Represents a potential short-term support.

resistance.description: Relevant resistance levels on the weekly timeframe. Oil has been below this zone for over 5 weekly candles - any rally expected to face strong selling pressure here.
Level where the correction attempt was rejected in April, coinciding with the turning point date at April 23. Strong immediate resistance.

technical.indicators: The weekly trend has clearly reversed to bearish after the break of the $62.50-$65.50 three-year support range. Five consecutive weekly candles below this zone confirm the breakdown. The rejection at $64.85 combined with the April 23 turning point date confirmed the bearish thesis. Trading cycles and high-volume patterns from the cycle methodology reinforce the view that any rally is an opportunity to sell rather than a trend reversal. The daily chart key support and resistance areas are plotted with Fibonacci levels from the attached chart in the report.

summary: Oil enters May 2025 with a confirmed bearish weekly trend after breaking through a three-year support zone ($62.50-$65.50). Key turning point dates are May 7-8, 16, 21-22, and 30. Despite a generally positive seasonal bias for May (73% probability of higher prices from May 6 to 13), the technical breakdown dominates the outlook. Resistance at $64.40-$66.50 is expected to cap rallies, while downside targets extend to $55.12, $51.00, and potentially $43.40 if the bearish momentum accelerates.
previous_month_review: April had four turning point dates with 50% hit rate, yet the captured moves were highly profitable. Date 1 (April 1) arrived exactly on time, marked the high of the preceding cycle, and delivered an approximately 18% decline to the next turning point at April 7 - a textbook cycle delivering a significant move. Date 2 (April 7) did not deliver the expected reversal - the price continued falling for two more trading days, effectively missing the exact bottom by a day or two. Date 3 (April 15) did not serve as a turning point for a move that was otherwise building - also marked as one that did not provide a trading opportunity. Date 4 (April 22-23, double cycle) arrived exactly on time, marked the high of the movement, and in combination with the retest of the previous resistance level around $65.20, initiated a decline of approximately 12.5% that is expected to continue through the first turning point date of May. Note: it is recommended to lock in profits before reaching the last low around $55.30 in case the gap between the two end-of-April/early-May dates creates a potential bounce.
risk_notes: The confirmed bearish weekly trend means any long positions carry significant counter-trend risk.
Resistance at $64.40-$66.50 is well-established and expected to trigger selling pressure on any rally.
Historical support at $51 is a major level - if broken, decline could accelerate toward $43.40.
Despite positive seasonal statistics, the technical breakdown takes precedence in the current environment.
Geopolitical factors (Iran, Panama Canal, global tensions) could create sudden supply shocks in either direction.
Even with a 50% hit rate, the methodology delivered substantial returns in oil - but proper risk management is essential.
Not investment advice - educational purposes only.
